Implicit Derivatives

Published : Wednesday October 7, 2015 — 12:00:00 AM EDT
  • :
  • test,
  • math

take the equation

Even though we can solve this for , we’ll assume that we can’t so we can showcase implicit derivatives.

An implicitly defined function is a function that takes the form , this example is the unit circle function.

To take derivatives of these functions, we need to treat as a function of .

With being a function of , we can use the chain rule to take the derivative of it, then treat or as an algebraic variable.

The best way to learn this is to do problems, so let’s do one.

  1. Take the derivative of the function and find the equation of the tangent line at
  1. constant rule, so
  2. power rule, so
  3. now comes the hard part. The variables disagree, we have to use the chain rule

when using the chain rule, we get

Now, let’s put it all together and do some algebra

Simplify, and done
